title: Trinity Christian outlasts Heritage School
text:
Trinity Christian outlasts Heritage School by Comments 
Heritage’s Karlie Groover tries to place the ball over the reach of Trinity teammates Cheyenne Hayes and Chasey Mitchell. 
A Region 1-AAA volleyball showdown on Thursday between Trinity Christian and host Heritage School featured the kind of drama fans have come to expect over the past two years. 
After splitting the first two sets, defending four time GISA state champion Trinity finally stepped on the accelerator for a 25-20, 23-25, 25-14, 25-18 victory to complete a difficult home-and-home series between the region rivals, each of whom reached last year’s state semifinals. 
The Lady Lions, who needed five sets to beat the Lady Hawks at home earlier this season, secured at least the No. 2 seed from 1-AAA with the victory, with region leader Oak Mountain now in their sights. 
“We still have a really big match next week against Oak Mountain,” said first year Trinity head coach Joe Herrera. “If we win that, it could come down to some sort of tiebreaker and then anything can happen.” 
The Lady Lions got plenty of support from team captains Cheyenne Hayes and Katie Jones. Hayes, a junior who has already committed verbally to play at Georgia Tech, finished the contest with 37 kills. Jones, among a large group of senior starters returning this year, led the defensive effort with 11 digs while setter Regan Lohlein posted 62 assists. 
Heritage was led by returning starters Kara Groover, Hallie Hunt and Zofia Powell. The contest ended a marathon day for Kara Groover and her sister Karlee, who helped lead the school’s softball team to a sweep of Terrell Academy earlier on Thursday a first-round state-playoff series. 
“They are special athletes,” Heritage head coach Mary Louise Hunt said. “To play two sports in the same season isn’t easy, but it’s something we have been able to work around, and they have done a great job handling.” 
After Trinity pushed the lead to 2-1, the Lady Hawks made them work to close out the match. Trinity shot itself in the foot several times with careless serves in the last set that put points on the Heritage side of the scoreboard. 
Trinity pushed the lead to 11-3 in the fifth set, before the Lady Hawks made one last run, cutting the lead to 19-14. 
“It was a lot closer than the score might show,” Herrera said. “It was to really good volleyball teams out there tonight. I think we did a really good job finishing.” 
Despite some poor serving early in the fifth set, an ace by Chasey Mitchell and Peyton Lohlein helped put the match away. 
Heritage took early control of the contest jumping out to a 13-9 lead in the first set, before Trinity used a 5-1 run the Lady Lions to tie it at 14-14. A kill by Hayes then gave the Lady Lions a lead for good in a 1-0 set advantage. 
The Lady Hawks rallied back to tie the match, jumping out to a 6-1 lead in game two and fighting Trinity off after it closed to 11-10 and 23-23. 
Trinity fought off a determined Heritage team early in the fourth set. After the Lady Hawks took a 9-8 lead, the Lady Lions closed out the game with a 17-5 run. 
Despite the loss to their biggest rivals, Hunt knows her team still has chances at the state tournament. 
“I thought we played really hard tonight,” she said. “We don’t have the height to match Trinity, so that makes it tough. But I am really proud of the way we played.” More
